1.text: Against Ptolemy ? Cosmography in Early Kalam

1.label: text
1.text: This article explores how mutakalliman engaged with competing visions of the cosmos traditionalist and Aristotelian - Ptolemaic - to the beginning of the sixth / twelfth century . Drawing on works of kalam , Quran commentary , and items from other genres , I demonstrate that rationalist theologians remained divided on such questions as the shape of the earth to the end of this period . These disagreements , moreover , cannot be explained in terms of school affiliation . Based on a compre- hensive examination of published sources , I argue that cosmographical opinion among mutakallimün was a function of exposure to late ancient learning , intellec- tual formation , and personal inclination more than doctrinal commitment .

3.label: text
3.text: For the purposes of this article , the Aristotelian - Ptolemaic cosmography is the view that the earth is an immobile sphere , nestled in the center of a series of concentric celestial orbs or shells . The precise number of orbs or shells , and the exact nature of their interaction , along with much else , was the subject of considerable disagreement among Aristotle and Ptolemy's interpreters and interlocutors in later centuries , Muslim or otherwise . 13 Notwith- standing their divergences , however , they " were in agreement with regard to the sphericity of the Earth and its position at the center of the universe , as well as the sphericity and the circular motion of the heavens . " 14 These fundamental features of the Aristotelian - Ptolemaic paradigm remained stable down to modernity , 15 and for this reason I choose to present them as a single model or paradigm .

3.label: text
3.text: This cosmography espoused by Muslim advocates of ' ilm al - nujum in the period surveyed is the alternative against which traditionalists defined themselves , as shall become clear . The traditionalist cosmography , to which I devote a separate section below , consists of belief in a flat earth , beneath which are a further six earths . Instead of the celestial spheres of the Aristotelian - Ptolemaic cosmography , there is a series of seven heavens ( either domed or vaulted ) , above which is God's throne ( ' arsh ) . What lies beneath the seventh and lowermost earth was , in the traditionalist corpus , subject to considerable disagreement . Nonetheless , the basic features of the traditionalist cosmography permit one to refer to it as a single model , or paradigm , since it remains remarkably stable .

Up to the early sixth / twelfth century there is no evidence of a trend of increasing accommodation of Greek cosmography by theologians of the four main rationalist schools . This remained true even as the distinction between astronomy ( Film al - hay'a ) and astrology ( aḥkām al - nujum ) emerged with greater clarity , and the former was ( increasingly ) shorn of metaphysical assumptions - developments that would clearly facilitate such an accommodation . 18 To make my case , I draw on the published corpus of kalām treatises of the period , along with Quran commentaries authored by theologians , and , occasionally , works from other genres . My evidentiary basis for these conclusions is com- prehensive , though by no means exhaustive , and will admittedly have to be revised as new sources come to light .

4.label: text
4.text: I begin with a brief survey of quranic cosmography . I then proceed to explore traditional- ist doctrine , and whether and to what extent it represents a departure from the vision of the cosmos presented in the Quran . I also attempt a characterization of traditionalist attitudes toward rival nontraditionalist viewpoints . These are necessary contexts for the study of the cosmography of the mutakallimūn , representing the standard against which they reacted . Their discussions show evidence of extensive engagement with cosmographical traditional- ism , sometimes by way of critique and at other times of adherence , in preference to the Greek alternatives . I then address the cosmographical views of individual rationalist theologians whose works are extant or whose opinions are preserved in later sources in more or less chronological order . This discussion forms the bulk of the paper .

7.text: Given the relatively late provenance of the extant sources , it is worth pausing to comment on the development of traditionalist cosmography in the postquranic period . I propose that this proceeded ( no later than the first half of the second Islamic century ) from two major impulses . The first was the explication of quranic material on the subject . The Prophet may have done this himself , and the same may be true of Ibn ' Abbas ( d . 68/687 ) and his circle , among other early Muslims credited for their activities in tafsir . 41 Much cosmographical material is also attributed to transmitters of the so - called Isra'īliyyat , 42 such as Ka'b al - Aḥbār ( d . ca. 32/652 ) and Wahb b . Munabbih ( d . 131/748 ) . Ascribing definite cosmographical views to any of these early figures is , of course , fraught with difficulty given the problems of the sources . Nonetheless , based on a perusal of the tafsir of Muqātil b . Sulayman ( d . 150/767 ) , the key features of traditionalist cosmography were evidently in circulation by the time of his death in 150h , that is , no later than the first half of the second century , and I shall adduce Muqatil's tafsir as evidence of the early date of various features of this cosmography . 43 The second major impulse was the attempt to situate the Prophet's life in the context of a broader sacred history . The Sira of Ibn Ishaq ( d . 150/767 ) is known to have originally consisted of three parts , the first of which , al - Mubtada ' , addressed origins and the history of the prophets to the emergence of Islam . 44 As such , it is extremely likely to have included cosmographical traditions . 45 Unfortunately , owing to the transmission of the Sīra , reconstructing this element of the text is likely to prove very challenging . 46

11.text: II . COSMOGRAPHY IN EARLY KALĀM : FIRST CONTACT

11.label: text
11.text: Muslim awareness of the Aristotelian - Ptolemaic cosmography predates the apogee of the Translation Movement by several decades . The earliest opinions on the subject from mutakallimūn , preserved in later doxographies and other sources , already reflect familiarity with Aristotle , as noted by Josef van Ess . 74 Hisham b . al - Hakam ( d . 179 / 795f . ) , a disciple of the Shi'i Imam Ja'far al - Sadiq ( d . 148/765 ) , played the leading role in introducing cosmo- graphical questions to kalām ; his lead was followed by younger contemporaries , including Abu al - Hudhayl al - ' Allaf ( d . 226 / 840f . ) and al - Nazzam ( d . 220/835 or 230/845 ) . 75 Though it is not clear precisely when the distinction between the " subtleties " ( daqiq , also latif , ghamiḍ ) and " main topics " ( jalil ) of kalām emerged , cosmography belonged firmly to the former domain and generated disagreement from the outset . 76 Cosmography was a standard feature of the discourse of the mutakallimūn , and the main lines of inquiry were already well estab- lished , before they received focused elaboration at the hands of theological systematizers toward the end of the third / ninth century . Cosmographical discussion in this period occurs in the context of questions of bodies , motion , and void ( i.e. , physics ) and , to a lesser extent , in the refutation of other religions . On all of these issues , dialogue and polemical exchange with non - Muslims seem to have been the main driver of opinion . The relative paucity of material on cosmography , moreover , suggests that it was rather incidental to larger , more narrowly " theological " debates .

12.text: As the first theologian known to have entertained views on Greek cosmography , Hisham b . al - Hakam's profile emerges with the faintest of clarity in the sources . He is reported to have refuted the opinion that the earth extends infinitely in all directions , which Aristotle attributes ( with some variation ) to Xenophanes of Colophon.77 The earth's suspension in place raised important theological questions about God's role in the maintenance of the cos- mos , hence the sustained interest of mutakallimün in the subject . Hisham is claimed to have taught that the earth rests on a body with a tendency to ascend ( jism sa " ad ) , which counter- acts the earth's tendency to fall , thus keeping the latter in place . 78 By seeking a rationalistic explanation for the earth's suspension , as opposed to assuming it rests ( e.g. ) on the back of a cosmic fish , Hisham implicitly rejects the traditionalist cosmography . There is , however , no hint in the sources as to his views on the shape of the earth . Hisham is also reported to have persuaded a Zoroastrian priest ( mūbadh ) that there is nothing beyond the ( finite ) cosmos , i.e. , that we would not be able to see anything or extend an outstretched hand beyond its bor- ders . 79 We also know that he was associated with corporealism , famously advocating God as the possessor of " a body unlike bodies , " located above the throne . 80 It is not clear , however , what bearing this had on his views on more strictly cosmographical questions .

12.label: text
12.text: Among Hisham's contemporaries , Abu al - Hudhayl and al - Nazzam entertained similar questions , and the extant sources are equally reticent on their views . Abū al - Hudhayl seems to have been the first mutakallim to refute the claim that the earth plummets downward per- petually . 81 His argument closely recalls De Caelo : a stone dropped to the ground lands there . 13.label: text
13.text: Collectively , the theological triumvirs Hisham , Abū al - Hudhayl , and al - Nazzam broached some of the major cosmographical issues that would preoccupy subsequent generations of mutakallimūn . Most prominently , they entertained opinions on the cause of the earth's immo- bility and on the finitude of the cosmos , usually in opposition to various non - Muslim groups . None is known to have addressed the earth's shape , or to have explicitly engaged with the traditionalist cosmography , however . In the case of al - Nazzam , this may be a result of his extreme scepticism toward hadith and other transmitted material , which he may have felt were beneath his attention . 89 With respect to Abū al - Hudhayl and Hishām , the possible rea- sons for this apparent lack of engagement with traditionalism are less straightforward . The absence may be simply a function of the paucity of source material . 90 Nevertheless , with these foundations , the basis for more systematic exploration of cosmography in kalām was laid .

14.label: text
14.text: The earliest cosmographical discussion in kalam for which we are not dependent on frag- ments and later doxographies comes from Kitāb al - Dalīl al - kabir of the Zaydi Imam al - Qāsim b . Ibrāhīm al - Rassi ( d . 246/860 ) . 92 Unlike Hishām , Abū al - Hudhayl , and al - Nazzām , al - Rassī spent most of his career in the cultural backwater of Medina , far removed from the cutting- edge developments of Baghdad and Basra . 93 He seems to have been relatively well informed on the cosmographical opinions of various non - Muslim groups , however , most likely as the result of a sojourn in Egypt , where he is known to have interacted with Jews and Chris- tians . Al - Rassi's cosmographical views emerge with a clarity atypical of earlier generations . He explicitly rejects cosmographical traditionalism , condemning the proto - Sunnis ( hashw hādhihi al - umma ) for their belief that the earth rests on the back of a fish ( hut ) . 94 He advo- cates the view that the earth is kept aloft by a mixture of void and air ( hawa ' ) beneath it , not- ing and dismissing the alternatives that the earth is , variously , the foundation of the cosmos , that it floats on a cosmic sea , that it seeks its " natural place " ( as per Aristotle ) , and that there is only void beneath it , or only air . 95 Kitāb al - Dalil al - kabir contains nothing on the shape of the earth , but it is not unlikely that al - Rassī pondered this question , though extant kalām sources do not address the issue until later in the century . 96

14.label: text
14.text: Al - Rassi's grandson and fellow Zaydi , Imam Yahya b . al - Husayn , known as al - Hādī ilā al - Haqq ( d . 298/911 ) , shared his disdain for the proto - Sunnis ( i.e. , mushabbiha ) , but rec- ognized the footstool as a physical structure encompassing the heavens and the earth . 97 He reports the " five hundred years " hadith in order to promote a sense of God's manifest great- ness in his readers ' hearts . 98 In another treatise he observes that the seven heavens and earths are held in midair ( fi al - hawa ' ) , without physical support , by virtue of divine fiat , much like Abū al - Hudhayl.99 His views are subtly different from those of his grandfather , but reflect comparable assimilation of Mu'tazili ideas and corresponding scorn for the proto - Sunnis .

" 100 Unlike al - Rassī and al - Hādī ilā al - Haqq , however , he enjoyed privileged access to the cosmographical knowledge of late antiquity through his residence in Baghdad and his association " with a group of translators of Greek philosophical works . " 101 His views on astronomy and astrology have been carefully reconstructed by Wilferd Madelung based on later texts . 102 Because the relevant work has already been done , I shall mention only a few of the most pertinent cosmographical points . Al - Nawbakhti is known to have written against Abū ' Ali al - Jubba'i's critique of the science of the stars . 103 Notwithstanding this , however , al - Nawbakhti was decidedly opposed to Aristotle , the pagans of Harran , and other exponents of that branch of learning . He produced an early account of the divergent views on the sub- ject among Muslims and non - Muslims that demonstrates extensive firsthand knowledge , including of Aristotle's De Caelo and its commentaries . 104 Al - Nawbakhti is not always con- sistent in naming some of the mutakallimūn associated with particular cosmographical opin- ions . 105 He ascribes the opinion that the earth rests " on the back of a fish [ ... ] on the horn of a bull [ ... ] standing on the ground ( thara ) " to a group among the proto - Sunnis ( qawm min ahl al - ḥadīth ) , without commenting on it . 106 Like Abu al - Hudhayl , al - Nawbakhti refutes the perpetual downward fall of the earth by appealing to the example of an object dropped to the ground ( a feather or a clod of mud ) . 107 Notwithstanding his very extensive exposure to late ancient knowledge , however , he remained " in outlook a Muslim kalām theologian , not a phi- losopher , " and shared " the basic rationalist principles of the Mu'tazila . " 108 His wide - ranging criticisms of the astronomers and astrologers ( Madelung's translations of munajjimūn and aşḥāb al - aḥkām respectively ) was to prove a valuable source for later theologians of dispa- rate tendencies , including the idiosyncratic Hanbali Ibn al - Jawzi ( d . 597/1201 ) . 109

18.label: text
18.text: In the course of the period , quranic hermeneutics came to figure prominently in kalām discussions of cosmography , perhaps for the first time . Most of the relevant material is found not in works of theology proper , but in Quran commentaries authored by mutakallimūn . The rationalist theologians seem to have turned to authoring full - length works of tafsir late in the third / ninth century , which forced them to confront cosmographical questions that might otherwise have eluded them . A number of key quranic verses emerged as the focal points for discussion ( appendix 1 ) .

18.label: text
18.text: The trends witnessed in the work of Abū ' Ali al - Jubba'ī and al - Ka'bī , the chiefs of the Basran and Baghdad Mu'tazilis , continued into the next period of cosmographical discus- sion in kalam , which is marked by considerable continuity but is also notable for its depar- tures . The major development is the theological careers of Abu al - Hasan al - Ash'arī and Abū Mansur al - Māturīdī . Neither seems to have been especially important during his lifetime , and one cannot speak of Ash'ari or Maturidi " schools " until well after their deaths . 131 Neverthe- less , with their advent one can retrospectively speak of the beginnings of what would become classical Sunni theology , with all that this entails for cosmographical doctrine .

Ibn Furāk provides the necessary information . He notes that al - Ash'arī held that " there is no reason for the suspension of the earth [ in place ] other than God's volition ( ikhtiyar ) . " 138 Of the four solutions documented in Maqālāt al - islamiyyin , this cor- responds most closely to the view , attributed to Abu al - Hudhayl , that the earth does not rest on a body . 139 Al - Ash'arī explicitly rejects , in good occasionalist fashion , all alternative causal accounts of the earth's immobility , whether produced by advocates of taba'i ' ( the four elemental qualities ) 140 or tawallud ( Mu'tazilis ) : " God , the most exalted , is the one who holds the earth [ in place ] , preserves , and oversees it , [ the one who ] renders the mobile bod- ies thereon immobile , by his will . " 141 Similarly , in al - Ash'ari's Risāla ilā ahl al - thaghr it is God alone who prevents the firmament from collapsing onto the earth ( echoing Q 22:65 ) . 142 Al - Ash'arī repudiated all claims about the inherent " nature " of bodies , whether it was the supposed tendency of fire to rise or of stones to fall , and , like Hisham b . al - Hakam , he denied that one could stretch a hand beyond the cosmos . 143 The view that the earth is hurtling downward , attributed by Ibn Fürak to the materialists ( Dahriyya ) , is rejected by al - Ash'arī , as is the ( more unusual ) opinion that it floats upward , also ascribed to them . The opinion that the earth is comprised of parts whose properties counteract each other ( the fourth solu- tion presented in Maqālāt al - islamiyyin ) is also refuted , as is the claim that it rests on a body that is re - created every moment for this purpose ( solution three ) : God instead re - creates the accident of motionlessness ( fi'l al - sukun ) in it every instant . 144 The bottom surface ( al - safiḥa al - sufla ) of the earth cannot be described as either immobile or moving , al - Ash'arī points out , seemingly because it cannot be described as having a place ( makan ) . 145 To summarize his contributions to the debate , al - Ash'arī takes the cosmographical framework of the Mu'tazilis as his point of departure , while rejecting most of the solutions they proposed to its most enduring problems , e.g. , the cause of the earth's immobility . His occasionalist commitments are the cause of these divergences . At no point in his extant work does al - Ash'arī explicitly reference traditionalist cosmography , though by denying that the earth rests on a body , he implicitly rejects one important element of it .

He notes three interpretations for the seven earths : that they are layered one above the other like the heavens ( as per the traditionalist view ) ; that these " earths " are in fact seven continents ( jaza'ir ) ; 149 and that the six earths are located somewhere beyond the lowest heaven ( al - sama ' al - dunya , Q 67 : 5 ) . Al - Māturīdī only affirms figurative interpretations of cosmographical data when the proper understanding of God's attributes is at stake , as in the case of the throne and the footstool . 151 He does mention the possibility that the firmament is not held up by pillars , but this view is also reported by the contemporaneous al - Tabarī , and has no necessary connection to the mutakallimūn as such . 152

21.text: Thus , by the early fourth / tenth century , key patterns of cosmographical thinking ( in the context of schools of kalām ) had emerged that would have a decisive bearing on subsequent developments . Following his conversion , al - Ash'arī committed himself to occasionalism— which would endure as a distinctive feature of Ash'ari theology - while retaining an interest in the kalām questions and methods of his Mu'tazili teachers , including those pertaining to cosmography . Al - Māturīdī's vision of the cosmos was , on the other hand , much more closely related to that of al - Tabarī than to that of the Mu'tazila , and he was not exercised by the same set of questions . Even among the Mu'tazilis , formative exposure to the traditionalist disciplines ( most importantly , hadith ) could produce a corresponding inclination , as we have seen with Ibn al - Ikhshīd . Overall , among these three theologians of clearly divergent view- points , theological affiliation is not an accurate index of cosmographical opinion . Similar conclusions may apply outside the Muslim community for this period : the Jewish mutakal- lim Dawūd al - Muqammaş ( d . ca. 325/937 ) , whom most scholars regard to have been deeply influenced by the Mu'tazilis , claims that the earth is discoid and the sky dome - shaped , in good Talmudic fashion . 155

21.text: In his study of the formation of the Sunni schools of law to the end of the fourth / tenth century , Christopher Melchert observes that the jurists of Baghdad were " usually leading the way , [ or ] almost always at least keeping pace . " 156 Wolfhart Heinrichs has also remarked that this period witnessed Islamdom's intellectual coming - of - age across the disciplines gen- erally . 157 Because of its role as the preeminent center of patronage , Muslim - non - Muslim encounter , and translation into Arabic , Buyid Baghdad played an oversize role in the his- tory of kalām in this period . The city was characterized by " frequent polemical encounters between members of the various groups . " 158 It figures prominently in the early history of the classical theological schools , with all that this entails for the development of cosmographical opinion . In this period the theological dissection of this material becomes more sophisticated as the classical theological schools crystallize ; some mutakallimūn , such as al - Balkhi and al - Shaykh al - Mufid , demonstrate a clear sympathy for the perspectives of the munajjimūn . None of the most basic points of cosmography was settled in theological discourse , however , and the disagreement does not clearly reflect school affiliation . Similarly , among the Twelver Shi'a , Ibn Bābawayh ( d . 380/991 ) established his reputation as star theologian of the community in Baghdad , before returning eastward . The career of his student al - Shaykh al - Mufid , a resident of the city , marked a major turning point in the his- tory of Twelver theology . Though there would be further eastward migration , especially by the Ash'aris ( for whom Nishapur became a major center ) , Baghdad retained its importance well into the fifth / eleventh century . This has a significant bearing on the transmission of cosmographical doctrine .

None of the dubious reports about the angelic bearers of the throne , he notes , is widely transmitted ( i.e. , they are aḥādī ) , and so do not constitute part of correct doc- trine . 171 Al - Mufid defines the cosmos ( ' alam ) in two places as " the sky and the earth , what- ever they contain and whatever is between them . 25.text: Among the Ash'aris of this generation , there was no reluctance whatever to critique the munajjimūn . ' Abd al - Qahir al - Baghdādī , a student of al - Isfara ini ( alongside whom he was buried ) , 188 condemns their views at length , deferring to largely traditionalist positions on cosmography . His exposition of the subject in Kitāb Usul al - din expands on the treatment in al - Ash'ari's Maqālāt al - islamiyyin , on which it is evidently based . 189 In the course of his sur- vey , al - Baghdādī mentions more obscure ancients , including Eudoxus of Cnidus ( Qanādūs , d . 337 BCE ) and Menelaus of Alexandria ( Mīlāwūsh , d . 140 CE ) . 190 Muslims , Jews , and Chris- tians , al - Baghdādī informs us , are all agreed that the earth is immobile , with the exception of the occasional earthquake afflicting its inhabitants . On this point , they concur with such luminaries as Plato , Aristotle , Ptolemy , and Euclid . Other opinions include the notion that the earth spins on its axis while remaining in place ( Eudoxus , and allegedly Menelaus ) , or the view that it is the earth that moves and the firmament that is fixed , contra the munajjimūn . 191 Following al - Ash'arī , al - Baghdādī's main purpose in the discussion is to argue that the earth remains in place only by virtue of God's power : " God [ ... ] has suspended it [ in place ] nei- ther by means of a body [ on which it rests ] nor by means of the air that encompasses it . 26.text: Like ' Abd al - Qahir al - Baghdādī , the Twelver naqib al - ashraf ( head of the Prophet's descendants ) , ' ālim , and man of letters al - Sharif al - Murtaḍā was keen to refute astrology . 196 Crucially , the astrologers ' accurate predictions of eclipses , he insists , ought not to be taken as a sign of the broader validity of their claims . 197 As a student of al - Mufid ( and leader of Baghdad's Twelver community after his death ) , 198 al - Murtaḍā unsurprisingly endorses the roundness of the earth ( against Abū ' Alī al - Jubba'ī ) , and like his shaykh ' Abd al - Jabbar , reads Q 18:86 figuratively . 199 Hussein Abdulsater characterizes al - Murtaḍā as largely pursuing established trends within rationalist Shi'ism , with some departures , and as having engaged much more critically with the Mu'tazilism of the school of ' Abd al - Jabbar . 200 Unlike al - Mufid , however , he identified more closely with the views of the Basran than Baghdad Mu'tazilis , but his disagreements with the former remain legion . 201

26.label: text
26.text: Abū Rashid al - Naysābūrī was also a student of ' Abd al - Jabbar , whom he succeeded as the leading theologian of the Bahshami school . 202 Al - Naysābūrī had defected from the Baghdad wing of the Mu'tazilis , and so his account of the differences between them , Kitāb al - Masa'il fi al - khilaf , is an invaluable source . In it he reviews the debate on the shape of the earth , finally upholding its flatness against the claims of Aristotle's De Caelo and Ptolemy's Almagest . 203 Al - Naysābūrī produces three main arguments to prove the earth is flat , in addi- tion to refuting several objections . If the earth were round , he writes , it would be equidistant at all points from the firmament , like a dot drawn at the center point of a circle . If this were the case , one would not see the sun rise and set , nor would it appear higher and lower in the sky at various points during the day , increasing and decreasing in size , because it would not move farther from or draw closer to the earth in the course of its daily cycle . 204 Furthermore , bodies of water would not remain in place on a round earth ; there would be nothing to keep them from falling into the surrounding air . Finally , the earth's roundness contradicts the straightforward meaning of Q 79:30 , according to which God spread out or " flattened " the earth ( daḥāhā ) following its creation . 205 While al - Naysābūrī does note that this verse can be interpreted as referring to parts rather than to the whole of the earth ( the view favored by al - Murtadā ) , he does not ultimately agree . 206 He does not express his opinion in a tone that

Like most of the leading Twelver theologians of his generation , al - Ṭūsī had studied under al - Mufid as well as al - Murtaḍā . 209 He authored major works in the domains of fiqh , kalām , and hadith , though it is his Quran commen- tary ( among his extant published titles ) that shows the most engagement with cosmography . Al - Ṭūsi concurs with Abū ' Ali al - Jubba'ī that the firmament is not held up by pillars , 210 and like him refuses to identify the quranic heavens ( samāwāt ) with the spheres of the astrono- mers , on the grounds that the former ( like the earth ) are immobile . 211 Al - Ṭūsī also affirms the existence of the seven earths , but implies that six are uninhabited . 212 His tafsir bears the impress of Abū ' Ali's , so it is perhaps no surprise to note that , like al - Murtaḍā , he inclined to Basran positions .

27.label: text
27.text: Though Baghdad was to remain important as a hub of interaction between the various theological schools , by the time of the Saljuq invasion of 447/1056 , many of these had estab- lished their main intellectual centers elsewhere . This was particularly true of the Ash'aris , now ensconced in Nishapur , and would soon be the case for the Twelver Shi'a . The aggres- sively anti - Shi'i stance of the Saljuqs radically constrained their opportunities to attract patronage . 213 The Maturidis remained an eastern concern at this point . I was able to find little cosmographical material in any of their extant published kalām texts of the period . Abū Shakur al - Salimi's ( d . after 460/1068 ) al - Tamhid fi bayan al - tawhid focuses its critique of the munajjimūn on astrology , revealing nothing of al - Salimi's cosmographical commitments . 214 Somewhat more promisingly , Baḥr al - kalām of Abū al - Mu'in al - Nasafi ( d . 508 / 1114f . ) denounces the astronomers ' belief that the lowermost of the heavens ( al - sama ' al - dunya ) contains only the moon among the celestial bodies . 215

Unfortunately , his own opinions are frustratingly hard to pin down . 216 Among the Ash'aris , ' Abd al - Qahir al - Baghdādī comes closest to adopting the traditionalist view of the cosmos , but owing to the paucity of the sources , it is impossible to state how far exactly this agreement extends . 217 Imam al - Haramayn ( d . 478/1085 ) reiter- ates the standard Ash'ari view on the immobility of the earth against some of the ancients , without further comment . 218

28.label: text
28.text: Thus , by the end of that century , the disagreement among mutakallimūn on cosmography was far from being resolved , and such little nodes of common opinion as I have been able to find do not fit readily into patterns of school affiliation . This is perhaps unsurprising given cosmography's location in daqiq al - kalām , beyond the domain of " theology " proper and so subject to perennial dispute ( at least in theory ) . Nevertheless , it seems clear that the practitio- ners of scientific astronomy had not made tremendous headway in persuading the theological thought - leaders of Islamdom to accept even their premises , e.g. , the roundness of the earth or the earth's location at the center of a system of concentric heavenly spheres . These con- cessions would eventually emerge among theologians , but not in the period under scrutiny . Though it can hardly be much more than conjecture , given the state of the field , I would like to suggest in parting that al - Ghazālī made a significant contribution toward facilitating the rehabilitation of the Aristotelian - Ptolemaic view ( at least in its broadest outlines ) . 219 Judging from the evidence of its citation history , the material on the cause of eclipses in his al - Mungidh and Tahāfut seems to have exercised broad influence . 220 If proven , al - Ghazālī would seem to have had the same effect on rehabilitating Greek cosmography as he did on logic . The two are interesting parallel cases , beginning on the margins of theological discourse before working their way into the disciplinary toolkit of postclassical religious learned culture . 221 Mounting this argument in detail is evidently beyond the scope of this paper . 30.text: Ibn ' Abd Rabbih 227 criticizes al - Balansi on five points : his problematic theology ( 1.2 ) ; his allegiance to a mathematically determined qibla ( 1. 3 ) ; his advocacy of astrology ( II . 4-5 ) , and his belief in a spherical earth and heavens ( 11. 5-6 ) . On all of these points , al - Balansi con- tradicts traditionalist doctrine . On the second charge , specifically , one should note that early Muslims relied on nonscientific means for determining the direction of the Ka'ba ( along with prayer times , etc. ) . The adoption of other ( mathematical ) means , following the translation of late ancient learning into Arabic , met with resistance in Iberia ( and presumably elsewhere ) , as noted by David King . 228 Ibn ' Abd Rabbih's main argument against the roundness of the earth seems to be that lands separated by vast distances experience the same seasons at the same time . Were the earth round , he suggests , this would not be the case .
